newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia to require Cyrillic labels on imported food.
newsitem.headline: Russia to require Cyrillic labels on imported food.

text.p: Russia will require all imported food to carry Russian-language labels detailing ingredients, manufacturing dates and other consumer information from May 1, according to a government decree published on Tuesday.
The decree, reported by the official Itar-Tass news agency, said labels would also have to specify calorie content, usage instructions and the name and country of the producer.

Tass said food importers would be responsible for ensuring all products were labelled in Cyrillic, but did not say whether exporters or importers would be responsible for actually placing labels on products.
Imports comprise up to one half of the Russian food market.
Tass did not say how frozen products, such as U.S. chicken parts, which Russian stores sell without packaging, would have to be labelled.
Moscow has complained that imported food of poor quality and past its sell-by dates is flooding Russian shelves.
